According to ACLED the Fulani militias deliberately killed 853 civilians so far. This might feel close to 1.000, but I think it is not. Since 1. August 2016 an overall of 151 civilians have been killed by the Fulani. That 147 more will get killed in December alone seems improbable (though certainly not impossible) to me. While there have been incidents with a lot of deaths - mainly the 300+ deaths in the attack in February - they luckily are rare.
Remember that the criteria set forth here for "mass killing" include inter alia at least *one thousand* dead. Killing 150 protesters falls well short of that.

“This deadly repression of pro-Biafra activists is further stoking tensions in the south east of Nigeria. This reckless and trigger-happy approach to crowd control has caused at least 150 deaths and we fear the actual total might be far higher,” said Makmid Kamara, Interim Director of Amnesty International Nigeria.
https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/11/peaceful-pro-biafra-activists-killed-in-chilling-crackdown/

According to Wikipedia, there have been 34 events since 1967; averaging per month, the rate is 0.05782. The WP list says the list is incomplete, so I multiply this rate by 2. Assuming that the number of events follow a Poisson distribution, the probability of one event happening in one month is 10.3%.
Adjusting down for the passage of time.

Decreasing to below census (counteracting previously high forecast) not because mass killing has/will not occur but because events will not be reported.

Even if the monthly average for 2016 (about 70 per month) continued in Nov/Dec, that would still fall short of 900 total.  And that's unlikely given seasonality.

Millions are at risk or are starving in Nigeria right now.  Death by Starvation secondary to civil war and insurgencies may not be technically genocide. But with millions at risk, I respectfully draw your attention to this analysis. http://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/world/2016/10/13/they-survived-boko-haram-now-millions-in-nigeria-face-a-new-threat-starvation/?wpisrc=al_alert-COMBO-exclusive%252Bnational%252Bworld ‘A famine unlike any we have ever seen’
As Nigeria battles Islamist terrorists, millions are at risk of starvation
Story by Kevin Sieff 
Photos by Jane Hahn
Published on October 13, 2016
Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on Google Plus Share via Email More Options 
BANKI, Nigeria — They survived Boko Haram. Now many of them are on the brink of starvation. Across the northeastern corner of this country, more than 3 million people displaced and isolated by the militants are facing one of the world’s biggest humanitarian disasters. Every day, more children are dying because there isn’t enough food. Curable illnesses are killing others. Even polio has returned. About a million and a half of the victims have fled the Islamist extremists and are living in makeshift camps, bombed-out buildings and host communities, receiving minimal supplies from international organizations. An additional 2 million people, according to the United Nations, are still inaccessible because of the Boko Haram fighters, who control their villages or patrol the surrounding areas. Above: Adama Adam, 15, cries next to the body of her six-month-old daughter, Fana Ali, at their home in Banki, Nigeria, on Sept. 28. Fana was brought to a clinic suffering from malaria and severe acute malnutrition. Doctors decided that she needed treatment at a hospital, but their request for a military escort through the war zone was denied without explanation and Fana died a short time later.
“We will see, I think, a famine unlike any we have ever seen anywhere,” unless immediate assistance is provided, said Toby Lanzer, the top U.N. official focused on humanitarian aid for the region. The staggering hunger crisis created by the insurgents has been largely hidden from view, partly because it has been extremely dangerous for aid groups and journalists to visit the area. But institutional failures have exacerbated the situation: For over a year, the United Nations and humanitarian groups dramatically underestimated the size of the disaster, and the Nigerian government refused to acknowledge the huge number of people going hungry in Africa’s second-richest nation. Thousands of people have already died because of the inaction, aid experts say. “It’s just a complete failure of the system,” said Natalie Roberts, an emergency program manager with Doctors Without Borders, an international aid group. It took over a year for U.N. humanitarian teams to arrive in cities that were “liberated” from the rebels by the Nigerian military in a major offensive starting in early 2015. Until recently, the United Nations had only tiny staffs working in the northeast. The world body had deferred to Nigeria’s woefully unprepared government agencies to provide assistance, not realizing, U.N. officials said, the scale of the disaster"

 In summary: https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/deconstructing-nigeria corruption  
Even more important  the historic and geographical  background.
While some are  skeptical of Strafor this is a great summary of the background:
"The challenges facing Nigeria date back to its foundation as a state. The country is geographically diverse: Swamps and marshes that dot the southern Niger Delta gradually transition into tropical forests and savannahs farther north, only to give way to the semi-arid climate of the Sahel. But Nigeria's population — at roughly 175 million people, the largest in Africa — is even more diverse than its landscape. The country is home to hundreds of ethnic groups, three major cultural groups (Hausa-Fulani, Yoruba and Igbo) and three major religious groups (Christianity, Islam and animism). These factors only begin to describe the many divisions in Nigerian society. The country's countless groups and subgroups, predictably, have made it incredibly difficult to govern as a single entity. Nigeria, in its modern form, first emerged as a British colonial concept following the 1914 merger of Lagos and the Southern and Northern Nigerian protectorates. Before that, the British had ruled the largely Christian south directly, leaving the mostly Muslim north to the region's entrenched political dynasties. After the joining of north and south, the two halves maintained a fair amount of sovereignty — a setup Nigeria has struggled to overcome since gaining its independence in 1960. Even as the concept of "One Nigeria" has gradually taken hold over the decades, the country's vast size and persistent rifts have proved stubborn obstacles to a truly united nation....... The geographic, ethnic and tribal divisions that exist in Nigeria also help to explain the vast economic discrepancies among the country's varied groups. Lagos, located in southwestern Nigeria, is home to the country's — and the continent's — busiest ports. The city, benefiting from West Africa's notorious lack of natural harbors and its sizable population, has become Nigeria's primary economic hub. Militancy, crime and a lack of development in Lagos' southeastern neighbor, the Niger Delta, have helped to reinforce the city's comparative prominence even more. All the while, grievances among Niger Delta locals over the exploitation of their region's natural resources have grown. Farther north, agriculture and livestock, rather than oil and ports, are the primary source of wealth. ,,,,,
the geographic, ethnic and tribal divisions that exist in Nigeria also help to explain the vast economic discrepancies among the country's varied groups. Lagos, located in southwestern Nigeria, is home to the country's — and the continent's — busiest ports. The city, benefiting from West Africa's notorious lack of natural harbors and its sizable population, has become Nigeria's primary economic hub. Militancy, crime and a lack of development in Lagos' southeastern neighbor, the Niger Delta, have helped to reinforce the city's comparative prominence even more. All the while, grievances among Niger Delta locals over the exploitation of their region's natural resources have grown. Farther north, agriculture and livestock, rather than oil and ports, are the primary source of wealth. In fact, the sector employs the vast majority of Nigerians. Yet in the extreme north, security threats largely stemming from Wilayat al Sudan al Gharbi — better known by its former name, Boko Haram — have severely weakened the region's economy. In places such as Borno state, more than 46 percent of children do not attend school, compared with the national average of 27 percent"

While the trend seems to go up, again, this is a volatile situation and I got no idea if this trend will continue. Just assuming that the mean will stay the same, this would lead to further 285 killed civilians during this year. However, as this year goes by, 148 civilians killed during 2015 won't count anymore. This leaves us with 285 additional civilians + the 699 civilians that have been killed in 2016 so far. Summing up to 984, this would mean that the number of the civilians killed by the Fulani will stay below 1.000. However, since the trend seems to continue to rise right now and the number is very close to 1.000, I am staying above 50%. Edit: On a sidenote, the violence inflicted by Boko Haram has been greatly reduced and they got pushed back in the north. In fact, during the first quarter of 2016 the Fulani killed slightly more civilians than Boko Haram (at least in Nigeria). However, as I had the opportunity to join a workshop by the International Crisis Group, they expect that Boko Haram will move further north - while fighters of the Islamic State in Libya may move further South. It is feared that they may inflict new crises in the states inbetween, e.g. Niger.

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.

"Meanwhile, significant violence has been recorded in the southeastern states of Benue and Taraba between January and April , with more recent fatalities reported in late April in Enugu (Vanguard, 26 April 2016). The perpetrators of the attacks are identified as nomadic Fulani herder militias engaging in cattle raiding against the settled farming populations of those states. There have also been reports of retaliatory violence and clashes between the Fulani militias and other communal groups (France24, 1 March 2016). The most fatal of these incidents was a series of attacks targeting Agatu communities in Benue, believed to have been carried out by Fulani militias, which killed at least 200 in late February 2016 (Vanguard, 14 February 2016). Last week, attacks attributed to Fulani militias were reported in Enugu, resulting in dozens killed after at least seven villages were attacked (IBT, 26 April 2016). These incidents represent a dramatic increase in violence in this region; violence of this type has historically been associated with the northern and central regions of Nigeria (Quartz Africa, 30 April 2016)...... In April 2016, the total fatalities reported from political violence in Benue, Enugu and Taraba (177 fatalities) overtook the fatalities reported in Borno State (164 fatalities), giving credence to the prospect that this new trend could be “the biggest security threat facing Nigeria after [Boko Haram’s] insurgency” (BBC News – Africa, 28 April 2016)." Also, from the Nigeria Security Tracker, http://www.cfr.org/nigeria/nigeria-security-tracker/p29483 , total deaths by perpetrators (excluding Boko Haram cases) between April 2015 and May 2016 are 1,116 by Sectarian Actor, and 987 by State Actor. That is starting to hit Nigerians rich and poor alike: On Monday, the country’s stock market fell almost 3% on news that MSCI is considering removing the country from its benchmark frontier markets index. Meanwhile, the World Bank said Nigeria’s economic growth slid to 2.8% in 2015 from 6.3% the year before, and the International Monetary Fund says this year’s growth will slip to 2.3%, slower than the population, which adds 13,000 people daily.

Boko Haram and the Nigerian government (in its fight against Boko Haram) are already considered to be perpetrating mass killings according to the desciption above. So their crimes do not weight in, unless they target a new group. In Nigeria, there are nontheless a number of different pathways to mass killings. In my view, they include herder/farmer violence (Fulani), violence between Shiites and the government and various secessionist movements. I am reposting two quick comments and some new data on the Fulani in response to @einsteinjs (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/172571). 1.) I decided to be a bit more cautious in regard to media reports: At the end of last year I substantially increased my forecast on mass killings in Nigeria, as reports stated that up to 800-1.000 Shiites have been killed in one single massacre by the military. Until now, the death toll remains foggy. There have been pictures of mass graves, digged by the military, but reliable information is rare. More recent articles put the death toll somewhere between 300 and 500. 
- http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/nigerian-military-under-scrutiny-after-shiite-group-clashes-1266287 2.) Also, there are a lot of articles that tend to blow threats inside Nigeria out of proportion, like this one about the Biafran secessionist movement in Nigeria. It states that "at best, a revitalized Biafran secessionist movement will lead to mass bloodshed. At worst, it will trigger the country's unraveling" and while it very plausible lays out this possible scenario & its background, it is keeping silent about the actual pathway or likelyhood of that event (the point, that would be of actual interest here). 
- http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/02/08/nigeria-is-coming-apart-at-the-seamsbiafra/?utm_content=buffer21c83&utm_medium=social&utm_source=facebook.com&utm_campaign=buffer 3.) Some data on the Fulani:
615 people, at least 546 civilians, have been killed by the Fulani in 2015, according to the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED). To determine the number of killed civilians, I used their “violence against civilians”-category, that should fulfil the criteria of the Early Warning Project. Between 1 January and 5 March 2016, according to preliminary ACLED-Data, the Fulani killed further 375 people, amongst them at least 358 civilians. This death toll already encompasses the Fulani attacks in Agatu, that according to ACLED led to 300 (civilian) deaths on February 24. Note that until now they just distributed the number over 5 different events&places (60 each). Summing up, this makes up for 904 civilian deaths in 15 months & five days.  We are looking for the number of civilians deaths within a period of 12 months here. Between February 24 2015 and February 24 2015, the Fulani killed 793 civilians. Thus the number until now does not surpass the 1.000 civilian deaths threshold. How likely is it, that it will surpass the threshold? Of course that depends how the situation on the ground will develop (cheap answer). If you take a look at the graph linked below, visualizing the aforementioned ACLED Data, Fulani-violence is (sadly) no new phenomenon to the region. A massacre on the scale of around 300 deaths however did not occur before.  Interactive graph:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1zHPmcEKYljndZQFY2ii_pwFI4XQH0N5SzNci_dSoQcM/edit?usp=sharing
(Edit: The timeline at the bottom is only roughly accurate; I did not combine the number of deaths reported at the same day but on different occasions; thus some days may get stretched out a bit by google while others where no deaths occured are not represented at all. The number of deaths & the given dates are accurate though.) Assuming that the violence returns to the average ‘normal’ level of 2015, even the additional 300 deaths of the recent massacre leave us with a max. of around 900 civilian deaths, in my view. However, just a second massacre of that scale would very likely tip the number over the threshold.

I'm surprised to see the aggregate forecast so high on this one. I wonder if people aren't noticing that Nigeria already has two ongoing episodes -- one non-state by Boko Haram, and one state-led associated with the government's attempts to quash Boko Haram -- and the continuation of these episodes would not count as new ones. Meanwhile, the Early Warning Project's last statistical risk assessment pegged the annual probability of an onset of state-led mass killing (other than the one associated with the counter-Boko Haram campaign) at 12.3 percent, the second-highest in the world. I see three situations now that present plausible scenarios for this to occur: the conflict with Shiites, the Biafran separatist campaign, and re-intensified conflict in the Niger Delta region. None of these situations is an obvious candidate for a non-state mass killing, and I don't see any others, so I'm just going to tack my best guess at the base rate onto the state-led estimate and start at 13 percent.

Nigeria has Boko Haram, which has committed several atrocities over the last few years (and the Nigerian Army has been accused of the same in retaliatory scorched-earth responses). Another flare-up can easily be envisaged. The EWP's statistical risk analysis has Nigeria second only to Myanmar, but whereas the latter is high-risk primarily because of a bad regime (which hopefully will be much less of the case in the coming months), it is due to the "Random Forest" machine-learning algorithm which is compiled from several factors.  EPW's crowd-sourced wikisurvey also ranks Nigeria as very high risk, behind only the Democratic Republic of Congo, Yemen, Syria, Burundi, Sudan and Libya, and above Iraq. So there are definite warning signals, and clear reason for them. On the other hand, EPW's expert opinion pool currently assigns 0% risk to Nigeria, down from 20% in early January, which means one should be cautious of going too high here. Also, several very high risk countries have gone several years without an episode.
